unit.title: Defensive Driving & Space Management
objectives: Adopt a defensive driving mindset that anticipates risk and reduces surprises.
Use scanning systems (SIPDE and the Smith 5 Keys) to see hazards early.
Maintain safe time/space cushions and adjust following distance for conditions.
Manage lane position, blind spots, and communication to avoid conflicts.
Apply the basic speed law and adapt speed for traffic, road, and weather.
Choose correct emergency responses (ABS braking, skid recovery, blowouts).

lessons.title: What Is Defensive Driving?
paragraphs: Defensive driving means choosing actions that reduce risk before a crash can develop. You expect other road users to make mistakes, and you leave yourself time and space to react.
A defensive driver plans routes, scans constantly, and keeps emotions out of the driver’s seat. You manage risk by controlling what you can: your speed, lane position, and attention.

lessons.title: Risk Triangle: Driver, Vehicle, Environment
paragraphs: Crashes usually involve a mix of factors: the driver (attention, decisions, impairment), the vehicle (tires, brakes, size), and the environment (traffic, weather, road design).
Reduce risk on all three sides: drive alert and sober, maintain your vehicle, and adjust to conditions like rain, darkness, or congestion.

sections.title: Seeing the Big Picture: Scanning Systems

lessons.title: SIPDE
paragraphs: SIPDE = Search, Identify, Predict, Decide, Execute. Search the road ahead, around, and behind. Identify potential conflicts. Predict how they might develop. Decide on the safest action. Execute smoothly.
Use SIPDE continuously—especially at intersections, lane merges, and around vulnerable road users like pedestrians and cyclists.

lessons.title: Smith System: 5 Keys
paragraphs: 1) Aim high in steering (look 12–15 seconds ahead). 2) Get the big picture (use mirrors; check sides). 3) Keep your eyes moving. 4) Leave yourself an out. 5) Make sure they see you (signals, lights, eye contact when possible).
These keys help you detect hazards early and preserve escape paths.

lessons.title: Eye Lead Time & Visual Scanning
paragraphs: In city driving, look at least 12–15 seconds ahead (about one city block). On highways, look 15–20 seconds ahead. Scan mirrors every 5–8 seconds.
Identify ‘stale’ green lights, hidden driveways, and vehicles that might enter your path. Early awareness buys time.

lessons.title: The 3–4 Second Rule
paragraphs: Pick a fixed object ahead. When the vehicle in front passes it, count ‘one-one-thousand, two-one-thousand…’. If you pass before 3–4 seconds on dry pavement, you’re following too closely.
Increase your cushion uphill, when towing, behind large vehicles, or when your view is limited.

lessons.title: When to Increase Following Distance
paragraphs: Add time in the rain, at night, in fog/smoke, on gravel, or when being tailgated. Also add space behind motorcycles and bicycles; they can stop or swerve quickly.
More time = more options. If someone tailgates you, create extra space ahead and avoid sudden braking.

lessons.title: Stopping Distance & Reaction Time
paragraphs: Total stopping distance = perception time + reaction time + braking distance. At higher speeds, distance grows dramatically.
Expect about a second of reaction time, longer if you’re distracted or tired. Leave space to account for that delay.

lessons.title: Lane Positioning
paragraphs: Use lane position to manage space: center (LP1) for general driving, left (LP2) to prepare for left turns/avoid right-side hazards, right (LP3) to prepare for right turns/avoid oncoming traffic.
Adjust position to keep a space cushion on at least one side.

lessons.title: Blind Spots & Head Checks
paragraphs: Mirrors don’t show everything. Before any lane change or merge, signal, check mirrors, and then turn your head to check blind spots.
Recheck after a brief pause; vehicles can appear quickly in fast traffic.

lessons.title: Communicating with Others
paragraphs: Use turn signals early (at least 100 feet before turning; on freeways, signal for about 5 seconds before changing lanes).
Tap your brakes to warn following drivers, use headlights when required, and avoid horn use except to warn of immediate hazards.

lessons.title: California Basic Speed Law
paragraphs: Never drive faster than is safe for current conditions—even if posted limits are higher. Slow for traffic, weather, road surfaces, and visibility.
‘Safe and reasonable’ speed changes minute by minute. Your judgment is part of defensive driving.

lessons.title: Work Zones & School Zones
paragraphs: Obey reduced speed limits, watch for workers and flaggers, and be prepared to stop. In school zones, slow down and yield to children and crossing guards.
Expect sudden changes: narrowed lanes, cones, and construction vehicles entering traffic.

lessons.title: Evasive Steering vs. Hard Braking
paragraphs: Steering around a hazard can be faster than braking—if you have an open path. If you need to brake hard with ABS, press the pedal firmly and steer where you want to go.
Avoid jerky inputs; smooth actions maintain traction and control.

lessons.title: Skids & ABS
paragraphs: For ABS: press and hold the brake; don’t pump. You may feel vibration—that’s normal. Steer to a safe path.
For a rear-wheel skid, ease off the accelerator and steer in the direction you want the front of the vehicle to go.

lessons.title: Tire Blowout or Wheel Drop-Off
paragraphs: If a tire blows out, grip the wheel, ease off the gas, and let the vehicle slow before steering to a safe stop. Avoid hard braking.
If your right wheels leave the pavement, hold a straight line, slow down, then gently steer back onto the roadway when clear.

lessons.title: Brake Failure / Overheated Brakes
paragraphs: If brakes fade, downshift to use engine braking and look for a safe area to slow and stop. Pump brakes if you do not have ABS.
Do not turn off the ignition while moving; you could lose steering control.

glossary.definition: Search, Identify, Predict, Decide, Execute—continuous hazard scanning model.
Five keys to defensive driving focused on vision, space, and communication.
Time and distance you maintain around your vehicle to react safely.
Drive at a speed that is safe for current conditions, regardless of posted limits.
Anti-lock Braking System that prevents wheel lockup during hard braking.
